//notes: manufacturer: Eagle Industries
we model this rucksack as having only one pocket inside the main compartment (instead of one large one and two smaller ones) for player experience
the plastic frame is supposed to eliminate discomfort from wearing rear ballistic plate with the backpack
modelling the pack uses proportional calculations
all volume values are in ml
all weight values are in g
calculations use volume values after first trim (for shape)
capacity is converted from 3000 cubic inches
description: A large-ish backpack with two exterior pouches and a plastic frame.  Developed after soldiers' request more than a decade ago, the medium rucksack fills the gap between the smaller assault pack and the large rucksack, successfully managing a good amount of internal space versus the comfort of its wearer.  The rucksack has a generous amount of MOLLE webbing on the outside, allowing you to mount several MOLLE pouches.  It also features a large hook-and-loop surface for identification patches.  Black letters "US" are printed on the top external pouch, over multicam.

notes: first trim is for shape relative to the box from dimensions
second trim is for collapsing the rucksack to its most folded state

//price: going with the price for best condition
that price was not immediately available at the time of creating the item
however, there's the highest-price indicator when no condition is selected, with the maximum being $199.99
given that 'Fair'-condition backpack costs $179.99, we can surmise that the highest price is for the best-condition pack

//notes: manufacturer: The Specialty Group, Inc.
sources disagree significantly on the dimensions of the pack, as well as on its volume capacity
we model the pack based primarily on pocket volume capacity, with compartment dimensions being considered of lower priority until a reliable source of both can be found
description: A soft nylon backpack with a secondary external pouch.  Adopted as part of the MOLLE II modular equipment system by the US Army and the Marines, it is the smallest of the three available packs, as it is intended to provide enough capacity for three-day excursions.  It is equipped with PALS webbing, which can be used to attach MOLLE pouches to the pack.  The main, larger compartment is fitted with equipment chutes for accessing the antenna of a large radio or a hydration bladder stashed inside.
//weight: main source appears to have mislabelled weight of the backpack in US units: metric weight is correctly listed as 1.8 kg, while US units weight is listed as 2 lbs (~907 g)

notes: first trim is for shape relative to the box from dimensions
second trim is for collapsing the rucksack to its most folded state

//notes: manufacturer: Point Blank Enterprises
the plastic frame is supposed to eliminate discomfort from wearing rear ballistic plate with the backpack
we are currently modelling the rucksack and the frame as a single item, for convenience and simplicity of design
we are also not modelling the large rucksack with two sustainment pouches, as it's often depicted, because they're not an inherent part of the rucksack
technically, the two compartments are not entirely separate, and one could, in theory, stash something long (20+ in.) in the rucksack
currently this capacity is not being modelled
the mesh-separated storage space in the top flap is currently also not being modelled
the extra few MOLLE cells on the flap are not modelled right now, either
modelling the pack uses proportional calculations
all volume values are in ml
all weight values are in g
calculations use volume values after first trim (for shape)
capacity is converted from 4000 cubic inches
description: A large, yet surprisingly light, nylon rucksack strapped to a rigid plastic frame.  Intended to be used for long excursions by active-duty military personnel, this pack could be stuffed with everything you might need on a long mission, and then some.  The bottom compartment is designed to fit a sleeping bag.  The rucksack has ample PALS webbing, on which one could fit a large volume of MOLLE pouches, including the two large sustainment pouches the rucksack often comes with.

notes: first trim is for shape relative to the box from dimensions
second trim is for collapsing the rucksack to its most folded state

second trim is for collapsing the rucksack to its most folded state
